summary: Build a clean, professional, minimalistic informational website titled “Mediation Made Simple – India” to promote public legal awareness of mediation in India, with role-based separate pages and interactive guidance tools.
architectural_notes: No external LLM/API integration; implement chatbot as a rule-based guidance engine using fixed dispute categories.
Role-based content should be implemented as separate pages (common person, lawyer, mediator, student, judge).
Recent Developments should support both public display of links/updates and an add/edit mechanism.
Remove the free-text “describe your dispute” chatbot-style guidance; keep only the fixed category-selection guidance tool and expand its per-category content.

existing_features.title: Create a clean, professional, minimalistic public website titled “Mediation Made Simple – India” with a homepage that includes: (a) a brief introduction to mediation, (b) the tagline “Not every dispute needs a courtroom”, and (c) prominent role-based navigation buttons linking to separate pages for: common person, lawyer, mediator, student, and judge.

Add core informational content sections (with user-facing text in English) covering: what mediation is, its evolution, application in India, and benefits; and provide a professional-but-approachable tone that avoids heavy legal jargon while maintaining legal accuracy.
Implement a “Mediation process” section with a toggle for two content modes: (1) simple language for general users and (2) a more detailed legal explanation for professionals.
Add a comparison table that contrasts Mediation vs Litigation vs Arbitration vs Negotiation in a clear, accessible, mobile-friendly layout.
Create separate role-based pages for common person, lawyer, mediator, student, and judge, each explaining relevant roles, duties, and rights (including the parties’ role) in the mediation context.

Build an interactive “My Dispute – What Should I Do?” guidance section where users select one dispute category from a fixed list and receive tailored, rule-based guidance on whether mediation is suitable and what to do next.

Add a chatbot-style rule-based guidance input that lets a user describe their dispute in free text and receive a tailored response based on the same fixed dispute categories (using keyword/rule matching), including a confidence/“best match” category label and a suggestion to choose a category manually if uncertain.

Create a “Recent Developments in Mediation in India” section that is visually appealing and displays a list of updates with external links; include functionality to add and edit updates (title, date, short description, URL).
Protect the add/edit “Recent Developments” functionality behind Internet Identity login, while keeping the public website content readable without login.

Apply a coherent visual theme across the site: neutral, minimal, modern editorial style using warm off-white backgrounds, charcoal/ink text, and a single muted accent color (not blue/purple), with accessible typography and consistent spacing.
Implement baseline accessibility and mobile friendliness across all pages: keyboard navigability, visible focus states, sufficient color contrast, and responsive layouts for common breakpoints.
Remove the free-text “Describe Your Dispute” chatbot experience from the “My Dispute – What Should I Do?” page, while keeping the category-selection experience as the only guidance workflow.

Expand the guidance content returned for each of the six fixed dispute categories in the category-selection tool to include substantially more specific, dispute-type-tailored information: (a) realistic examples, (b) mediation suitability guidance including when it may not be suitable, (c) clear next steps, (d) practical do’s and don’ts, and (e) legal-information notes written in plain English for India-focused context (informational, not legal advice).

Update the category-selection UI to present the new expanded guidance sections in a clear, scannable layout that remains mobile-friendly and accessible (e.g., headings, lists, and consistent spacing).

new_feature_requests.summary: Create minimalistic, mobile-friendly informational website “Mediation Made Simple – India” with homepage intro, tagline, and role-based navigation
Add content sections: what mediation is (evolution, application in India, benefits) and mediation process with dual modes (simple vs detailed legal)
Add comparison table: Mediation vs Litigation vs Arbitration vs Negotiation
Add sections describing roles/duties/rights of lawyers, mediators, referral judges, and parties
Implement “My Dispute – What Should I Do?” interactive tool with fixed dispute categories and tailored guidance output
Add “Recent Developments in Mediation in India” section with visually appealing static links plus ability to add/edit updates
Create separate role-based pages for common person, lawyer, mediator, student, and judge

Expand “My Dispute – What Should I Do?” category outputs with more tailored content per each of the six fixed dispute categories (examples, mediation suitability, next steps, legal info, do’s/don’ts) while keeping the category-selection UX

Update backend dispute guidance structures and logic so the category-based guidance API can deliver the expanded guidance fields needed by the frontend, with category-specific tailored content (not the current generic step list).
